title: How to Make Peppermint Candy Cane Truffles

steps.headline: Chop some excellent quality bittersweet chocolate, and set it aside in a large mixing bowl.
Bring the fresh heavy cream to the scald in a microwave.
steps.description: Be very careful to keep an eye on the cream, as it will quickly boil over as it reaches the boiling point.

steps.headline: Pour the scalding hot cream over the finely chopped chocolate immediately.
steps.description: With a rubber spatula stir in small circles, until homogeneous.

steps.headline: Add in room temperature unsalted butter, and a teaspoon of real vanilla extract.
steps.description: Stir until very smooth and shiny.

steps.headline: Allow the ganache to set up for approximately 30 minutes, or until it is the consistency of soft clay.
Place about 6-8 medium size peppermint candy canes in a heavy duty plastic baggie in the meantime.
steps.description: Smash up into bits with a heavy can, or a hammer if you happen to have one around the house.

steps.headline: Create small bite-size truffles using a small ice cream scoop  or just a teaspoon once the ganache has set up.

Place a palmful of crushed peppermint candy cane in one hand, and with the other hand, grab a chocolate truffle and roll the truffle in the peppermint bits between your palms until spherical and nicely truffle-shaped.
steps.description: The heat from your hands will help the peppermint bits to adhere to the chocolates.

steps.headline: This recipe should produce about 36 small peppermint candy cane truffles, so pile them up on an elegant serving platter for a lovely holiday treat!

text: Chop some excellent quality bittersweet chocolate, and set it aside in a large mixing bowl.  Bring the fresh heavy cream to the scald in a microwave. Be very careful to keep an eye on the cream, as it will quickly boil over as it reaches the boiling point. Pour the scalding hot cream over the finely chopped chocolate immediately. With a rubber spatula stir in small circles, until homogeneous. Add in room temperature unsalted butter, and a teaspoon of real vanilla extract. Stir until very smooth and shiny. Allow the ganache to set up for approximately 30 minutes, or until it is the consistency of soft clay.  Place about 6-8 medium size peppermint candy canes in a heavy duty plastic baggie in the meantime. Smash up into bits with a heavy can, or a hammer if you happen to have one around the house. Create small bite-size truffles using a small ice cream scoop  or just a teaspoon once the ganache has set up.  Place a palmful of crushed peppermint candy cane in one hand, and with the other hand, grab a chocolate truffle and roll the truffle in the peppermint bits between your palms until spherical and nicely truffle-shaped. The heat from your hands will help the peppermint bits to adhere to the chocolates. This recipe should produce about 36 small peppermint candy cane truffles, so pile them up on an elegant serving platter for a lovely holiday treat!
